quiz.title: Unit 9: Market Failure & Public Policy (Quiz 4)
quiz.subtitle: AP Microeconomics — Government Intervention, Price Controls, Taxes, Subsidies
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Price Ceilings, Price Floors, Tax Incidence, Subsidy Effects, Deadweight Loss

questions.question: A binding price ceiling set below the equilibrium price will result in
questions.explanation: A price ceiling below equilibrium prevents the price from rising to clear the market, leading to quantity demanded exceeding quantity supplied—a shortage.

questions.question: A binding price floor set above the equilibrium price will result in
questions.explanation: A price floor above equilibrium prevents the price from falling to clear the market, leading to quantity supplied exceeding quantity demanded—a surplus.

questions.question: The deadweight loss from a tax is caused by
options: the transfer of surplus from consumers to producers
the reduction in mutually beneficial transactions that no longer occur
the shift in the supply curve
questions.explanation: Deadweight loss is the loss of total surplus because the tax discourages some trades that would have been efficient (where marginal benefit > marginal cost).

questions.question: The incidence of a tax (who bears the burden) depends primarily on
options: who writes the check to the government
the price elasticities of supply and demand
questions.explanation: Tax incidence is determined by relative elasticity: the more inelastic side bears more of the burden because they cannot adjust quantity as easily.

questions.question: If demand is perfectly inelastic and a per‑unit tax is imposed, the burden of the tax falls
questions.explanation: When demand is perfectly inelastic, consumers cannot reduce quantity purchased in response to a price increase, so they bear the full tax burden.

questions.question: A subsidy granted to producers will shift the
questions.explanation: A subsidy lowers producers' costs, increasing supply at each price—a rightward (or downward) shift of the supply curve.

questions.question: Which of the following is a likely consequence of a binding price ceiling on rental housing?
options: Increased investment in new rental housing
A black market with higher prices for some renters
Higher quality of rental housing due to competition
questions.explanation: Binding rent controls create a shortage, leading to non‑price rationing (waiting lists, favoritism) and often illegal side payments or “key money” (black markets).

questions.question: A per‑unit tax on a good with relatively elastic demand and inelastic supply will result in
options: producers bearing most of the tax burden
consumers bearing most of the tax burden
questions.explanation: When supply is more inelastic than demand, producers cannot easily reduce quantity supplied, so they bear a larger share of the tax burden.

questions.question: The area of deadweight loss from a tax is a triangle between the
options: supply and demand curves from the new quantity to the old equilibrium quantity
price paid by buyers and price received by sellers
questions.explanation: Deadweight loss is the area between supply and demand curves from the post‑tax quantity to the pre‑tax equilibrium quantity, representing lost gains from trade.

questions.question: A minimum wage is an example of a
questions.explanation: A minimum wage sets a legal minimum price for labor (wage), making it a price floor. If set above equilibrium, it causes a surplus of labor (unemployment).

scoreMessages.90: Mastery of price controls, tax/subsidy effects, deadweight loss, and tax incidence based on elasticity.
scoreMessages.70: Solid grasp; review shortage/surplus from ceilings/floors, tax burden allocation, and subsidy shifts.
scoreMessages.50: Needs practice analyzing binding price controls, illustrating tax deadweight loss, and determining incidence from elasticities.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on price ceilings (shortage), price floors (surplus), tax DWL triangle, subsidy shifting supply, and tax burden falling on the inelastic side.
